newsitem.title: BOTSWANA: DE BEERS GETS NEW MINING LEASE IN BOTSWANA.
newsitem.headline: DE BEERS GETS NEW MINING LEASE IN BOTSWANA.

text.p: Diamond giant De Beers said on Tuesday the Botswana government had granted it a four-year mining lease for five kimberlite pipes at Martin's Drift near the border with South Africa.
The mine will be operated by Tswapong Mining Company, in which the government will have a 15 percent stake, with the remainder of the equity held by De Beers Prospecting Botswana.
"Work will commence on site shortly with bush clearing and road building," a De Beers statement said.
It said low yields were expected with a resource value below $10 per tonne. Overall expected mine life had not yet been determined.

De Beers project manager in Botswana, James Campbell, said he expected the first parcel of diamonds to be in the Botswana Orapa House sorting centre by the end of September. "We are aiming at fast track development," he said
Although the lease was for four years, the low resource value of the mine would effectively be a sampling exercise, he added.
"We cannot evaluate accurately before we start to mine because of the low yield," Campbell said.
"The essentially small scale mining exercise over the four year period will move enough tonnage to enable us to determine future mining prospects," he added
Open-cast mining with traditional recovery methods will be used at the mine.
